content.description: A block of mass <math alttext="0.4 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on a horizontal surface is attached to a horizontal spring of negligible mass and unknown spring constant. The other end of the spring is attached to a wall, and there is negligible friction between the block and the horizontal surface. When the spring is unstretched, the block is located at <math alttext="x equals 0 meters" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></math>. The block is then pulled to <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and released from rest so that the block-spring system oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>0.2</mn></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block-spring system undergoes 5 oscillations in <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: How could a student determine the change in spring potential energy of the system from <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> by using the diagram and the known information?

choices.label: By dividing 5 oscillations by <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the period of the system, using <math alttext="T sub s equals, 2 pi times, the square root of the fraction m over k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring constant of the spring, using <math alttext="U sub s equals, one half k times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring potential energy at <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and determining the magnitude of the difference of these two values.

By dividing 5 oscillations by <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the period of the system, using <math alttext="T sub s equals, 2 pi times, the square root of the fraction m over k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring constant of the spring, using <math alttext="U sub s equals, one half k times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring potential energy at <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and determining the sum of these two values.

By dividing <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> by 5 oscillations to determine the period of the system, using <math alttext="T sub s equals, 2 pi times, the square root of the fraction m over k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring constant of the spring, using <math alttext="U sub s equals, one half k times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring potential energy at <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and determining the magnitude of the difference of these two values.

By dividing <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> by 5 oscillations to determine the period of the system, using <math alttext="T sub s equals, 2 pi times, the square root of the fraction m over k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring constant of the spring, using <math alttext="U sub s equals, one half k times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring potential energy at <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and determining the sum of these two values.

content.answer: By dividing <math alttext="8 seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> by 5 oscillations to determine the period of the system, using <math alttext="T sub s equals, 2 pi times, the square root of the fraction m over k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring constant of the spring, using <math alttext="U sub s equals, one half k times x squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>U</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the spring potential energy at <math alttext="x equals 0.2 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals 0.1 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and determining the magnitude of the difference of these two values.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
